etymology_text: From Cato the Elder's practice of ending every speech, no matter the topic, with ceterum censeo Carthaginem esse delendam ("furthermore, I propose that Carthage is to be destroyed").

etymology_text: From Proto-Italic *-kÊ·e (â€œandâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *-kÊ·e (â€œandâ€). Cognates include Sanskrit à¤š (ca), Ancient Greek Ï„Îµ (te), Proto-Germanic *-hw ( â†’ English (thou)gh). Its alternative use as a generalizing particle "any, -every" with pronouns and adverbs may result from a shift from an earlier meaning along the lines of "as". There are also a number of words that are etymologically suffixed with this particle but that have developed specific meanings not clearly analyzable in terms of either of these senses, such as dÄ“nique (â€œfinally; at lengthâ€).

examples.text: quis (â€œwhoâ€) + -que (â€œ-everâ€) â†’ quisque (â€œwhoever; anyone; each oneâ€)
cum (â€œwhenâ€) + -que (â€œ-everâ€) â†’ cumque (â€œwhenever; howeverâ€)
ubÄ« (â€œwhereâ€) + -que (â€œ-everâ€) â†’ ubÄ«que (â€œwherever, anywhere, everywhereâ€)

glosses: -ever; every-, any-; every, each ('universalizing' or 'generalizing' particle found in a fixed set of indefinite pronouns and adverbs)

etymology_text:
From Old Latin olle (â€œhe, thatâ€) (also ollus, olla), from Proto-Italic *olnos, from Proto-Indo-European *hâ‚‚ol-no-s or *hâ‚‚lÌ¥-no-s, from *hâ‚‚el- (â€œbeyond, otherâ€). Cognate with Latin uls (â€œbeyondâ€), alius (â€œotherâ€), and alter (â€œthe otherâ€); Umbrian ulu (â€œto that placeâ€), Old Church Slavonic Ğ»Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¸ (lani, â€œlast yearâ€, literally â€œin that (year)â€).
Initial i- from o- has no parallel case and may be owing to contamination from is, iste or due to the palatalizing effect of l exilis.

etymology_text:
Adopted from the thematic vowel in Ancient Greek -Î¿- (-o-) and -ÏŒ- (-Ã³-), often used to form nominal compounds. In Ancient Greek, the connective suffix originates in compounds where the first member is thematic, such as Î´Î·Î¼Î¿ÎºÏÎ±Ï„Î¯Î± (dÄ“mokratÃ­a), but was extended by analogy to other stems, such as Î¼Î·Ï„ÏÏŒÏ€Î¿Î»Î¹Ï‚ (mÄ“trÃ³polis). The suffix was borrowed as a connective into Latin, mainly in compounds of Greek origin.
The suffix becomes productive and forms new compounds in learned humanist Latin, from the Renaissance. The connective is especially productive in connecting ethnonyms or geographical terms; genuine Greek stems include Gallo-, and Syro-, but most are of medieval or modern origin, productive from the 15th century, such as Anglo-, Graeco- or Latino-.

raw_glosses: (post-classical Latin) Suffix forming nominal compounds (such as anglosaxonicus (â€œAnglo-Saxonâ€), from Anglus (â€œAngle, Englishâ€) and saxonicus (â€œSaxonâ€)).
glosses: Suffix forming nominal compounds (such as anglosaxonicus (â€œAnglo-Saxonâ€), from Anglus (â€œAngle, Englishâ€) and saxonicus (â€œSaxonâ€)).

etymology_text: From the reduction of several historical unstressed short stem vowels during the Old Latin period. The reduced vowel was later reinterpreted as part of various suffixes.

glosses: Connecting vowel inserted between a stem and a suffix in compound words.
